title: U-substitution
text: An ideal strategy is to select "u" as a function and its derivative that appears within the integral.
speech: An ideal strategy is to select "u" as a function and its derivative that appears within the integral.
pacedSpeech: An ideal strategy is to select "u" as a function and its derivative that appears within the integral.

title: U-substitution
text: What should we set u equal to?

subHints.title: U-substitution
subHints.text: The reason why we want to set $$u=1+cosx$$ is because that expression is on the denominator and we know that $$\frac{d}{\operatorname{dx}\left(1+cosx\right)}=-sinx$$. So that $$du=-sinx$$ or $$-du=sinx$$ which is an expression on the numerator

speech: What should we set u equal to?
pacedSpeech: What should we set u equal to?

title: Using u-substitution
text: Bringing the negative sign outside the integral sign, the problem now reads $$-\int u^{\left(-1\right)} \,du$$.
speech: Bringing the negative sign outside the integral sign, the problem now reads  minus the integral of u raised to the parentheses negative 1  power d u .
pacedSpeech: Bringing the negative sign outside the integral sign, the problem now reads   minus the integral of u raised to the  negative 1  power d u

title: Change the limits
text: After setting f(x) to f(u), you need to change the limits of integration because the variable of integration has changed from $$x$$ to u.
speech: After setting f(x) to f(u), you need to change the limits of integration because the variable of integration has changed from  x  to u.
pacedSpeech: After setting f(x) to f(u), you need to change the limits of integration because the variable of integration has changed from   x

title: Change the limits
text: As $$u=1+cosx$$, we will have upper and lower limits $$x=1$$ and $$x=2$$ respectively.
speech: As  u is equal to 1 plus, c o s x, , we will have upper and lower limits  x is equal to 1  and  x, is equal to 2  respectively.
pacedSpeech: As   u is equal to 1 plus, c o s x,
, we will have upper and lower limits   x is equal to 1

title: Interchange the limits
text: Notice that now the limits begin with the larger number, meaning we must multiply the whole integral by $$-1$$ and interchange the limits.
speech: Notice that now the limits begin with the larger number, meaning we must multiply the whole integral by  minus 1  and interchange the limits.
pacedSpeech: Notice that now the limits begin with the larger number, meaning we must multiply the whole integral by   minus 1

title: Rewrite the integral in term of u
speech: minus the integral from 2 to 1 of u raised to the parentheses negative 1  power d u is equal to the integral from 1 to 2 of u raised to the parentheses negative 1  power d u

title: Find the integral
text: $$\int_{1}^{2} u^{\left(-1\right)} \,du=ln|u|$$ with the limit goes from $$u=1$$ to $$u=2$$
speech: the integral from 1 to 2 of u raised to the parentheses negative 1  power d u is equal to l n the absolute value of u  with the limit goes from  u is equal to 1  to  u, is equal to 2
pacedSpeech: the integral from 1 to 2 of u raised to the  negative 1  power d u is equal to l n the absolute value of u
with the limit goes from   u is equal to 1

title: Evaluate the integral
speech: l n 2, minus l n 1 is equal to, l n 2
pacedSpeech: l n 2, minus l n 1 is equal to, l n 2
